questions.question: What is the main purpose of meiosis?
options: To produce gametes (sex cells) with half the chromosome number
To replicate somatic cells for the purposes of tissue repair
To increase the total number of chromosomes within a zygote
To convert haploid stem cells into diploid specialized cells
questions.explanation: Meiosis produces gametes (sperm and eggs) that have half the normal chromosome number. This ensures fertilization restores the full chromosome number.

questions.question: How many divisions occur during meiosis?
options: Two divisions (Meiosis I and Meiosis II)
One division similar to standard mitosis
Three divisions to maximize genetic variation
A variable number depending on the organism
questions.explanation: Meiosis consists of two consecutive divisions: Meiosis I separates homologous chromosomes, and Meiosis II separates sister chromatids.

questions.question: What happens to chromosome number during meiosis?
options: It is halved (diploid to haploid)
It remains constant (diploid to diploid)
It is doubled (haploid to diploid)
It fluctuates randomly during the second division
questions.explanation: A diploid (2n) cell undergoes meiosis to produce haploid (n) gametes. This reduction is crucial so fertilization can restore the diploid number.

questions.question: What is 'crossing over' and when does it occur?
options: Exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes during Prophase I
Separation of individual sister chromatids during late Anaphase II
The alignment of tetrads along the metaphase plate of the cell
The final division of the cytoplasm during the cytokinesis phase
questions.explanation: Crossing over occurs when homologous chromosomes pair up and exchange segments during Prophase I. This creates new combinations of genes, increasing genetic variation.

questions.question: How many daughter cells result from meiosis?
options: Four genetically different haploid cells
Two genetically identical diploid cells
Two genetically different haploid cells
Four genetically identical haploid cells
questions.explanation: One diploid cell undergoes meiosis to produce four haploid gametes. These four cells are genetically different from each other and from the parent cell.

questions.question: What are homologous chromosomes?
options: Chromosome pairs (one from each parent) with similar genes
Identical sister chromatids produced during the S phase
Chromosomes containing entirely unrelated genetic instructions
The specific pair of sex chromosomes designated as X and Y
questions.explanation: Homologous chromosomes are matching pairs - one inherited from the mother, one from the father. They carry genes for the same traits but may have different alleles.

questions.question: What is independent assortment and why is it important?
options: Random alignment of homologous pairs during Metaphase I, creating genetic variation
The physical separation of the cytoplasm into four distinct daughter cells
The biochemical replication of DNA before the meiotic process begins
The pairing process of homologous chromosomes during the Prophase I stage
questions.explanation: During Metaphase I, homologous chromosome pairs line up randomly at the equator. This random orientation means each gamete gets a random mix of maternal and paternal chromosomes.

questions.question: Where does meiosis occur in animals?
options: In gonads (testes and ovaries)
In all somatic cells to facilitate growth
Exclusively within the red bone marrow
In epithelial cells to assist with repair
questions.explanation: In animals, meiosis occurs only in gonads: testes produce sperm (spermatogenesis) and ovaries produce eggs (oogenesis).

questions.question: How does meiosis contribute to genetic variation in offspring?
options: Through crossing over and independent assortment
By producing clones of the original parental cells
By doubling the chromosome count in every gamete
By suppressing mutations during the replication phase
questions.explanation: Crossing over mixes genes on chromosomes, and independent assortment randomly distributes chromosomes to gametes. These processes ensure each gamete is genetically unique.

questions.question: What would happen if meiosis produced diploid gametes instead of haploid?
options: Chromosome number would double with each generation
The resulting offspring would have half the normal chromosome count
Genetic variation would be completely eliminated from the population
The process of fertilization would become physically impossible
questions.explanation: If diploid (2n) sperm fertilized a diploid (2n) egg, the zygote would be tetraploid (4n). This would lead to an exponential increase in chromosome number each generation.
